class vizasm.analysis.asm.cpu.AsmRegEx.AsmRegEx[source]¶

Bases: vizasm.RegEx.RegEx

Contains regular expressions (mostly in verbose mode) used for analyzing the assembler file

Parameters:

RE_SELECTOR :

match e.g. “@selector(objectForKey:)”

RE_BASIC_BLOCK :

match e.g. ”; Basic Block Input Regs: rax rdx rsi rdi - Killed Regs: rax rcx rdx rsp rbp rsi rdi r8”

RE_METH_IMPL :

match e.g. “methImpl_AppDelegate_applicationDidFinishLaunching_” or “methImpl_static_Segment_demangleNoSuffix”

RE_CATEGORY :

match category method like e.g. “+[NSURLRequest(AnyHttpsCert) allowsAnyHTTPSCertificateForHost:]_100002120:” (static category method) or “-[NSURLRequest(AnyHttpsCert) initWithURL:cachePolicy:timeoutInterval:]_100002060:” (class category method)

RE_HEX_VALUE :

match e.g. “OxFF or 0xff” or “#0xFF” (arm)

SEARCH_NOP :

use to search for nop command

RE_MATCH_ENTRYPOINT :

use to identify entry point in asm file

RE_OWN_C_METHOD_DEF :

match .e.g “// cFunction(int, int, int)”

RE_OWN_C_METHOD_CALLED :

match e.g. “cFunction(int, int, int)”

RE_SUB :

match e.g. “sub_1001bc366:”

RE_CALLED_SUB :

match e.g. “sub_1001bc366”

RE_C_METHOD :

match e.g. “_CGPointMake_10002c4e0_1:”

RE_CALLED_C_METHOD :

match e.g. “_CGPointMake_10002c4e0_1”

RE_CLASS_PARENT :

match e.g. “Class Object1 (parent class: SuperObject)”

RE_FORMAT_STRING :

match e.g. @”“%s%d’ but not ‘@”%%”’ and not ‘@”Defaults”’. The string must contain a format argument like e.g. %@

RE_STRING :

match e.g. ‘@”defaults”’

Methods

compiled_re(regex[, flags]) Returns a compiled regex pattern object Flags will only be passed if not None.
compiled_vre(regex[, flags]) Returns a compiled regex pattern object
is_entrypoint(asmline) Check if line is entry point in asm file (See AsmRegEx.RE_MATCH_ENTRYPOINT)
is_method_implementation(asmline) Indicates if a line is a CategoryClass or method implementation.
method_implementation_is_static(...) Returns if the method is static
RE_BASIC_BLOCK = '\n Basic\\ Block\\ Input\\ Regs\\:\\s* # ; Basic Block Input Regs: \n (?P<input_regs>[\\w <>]+) # rax rdx rsi rdi\n \\s+-\\s+ # - \n Killed\\ Regs\\:\\s* # Killed Regs: \n (?P<killed_regs>[\\w ]+) # rax rcx rdx rsp rbp rsi rdi r8\n \\s*\n'¶
RE_BASIC_BLOCK_INPUT_REGS = 'input_regs'¶
RE_BASIC_BLOCK_KILLED_REGS = 'killed_regs'¶
RE_CALLED_C_METHOD = '\n _+ # _ \n (?P<c_method_name>\\S+) # CGPointMake_10002c4e0_1\n $'¶
RE_CALLED_C_METHOD_GR_NAME = 'c_method_name'¶
RE_CALLED_SUB = '\n (?P<subname>\n sub[_] # sub_\n \\S+) # 1001bc366\n $'¶
RE_CALLED_SUB_GR_SUBNAME = 'subname'¶
RE_CATEGORY = '\n (?P<selector_type>[+]|-)+ # starts with + or -\n \\[ # [ \n (?P<on_class>\\w+) # NSURLRequest\n \\((?P<class>\\w+)\\) # AnyHttpsCert\n \\s+ # whitespace\n (?P<selector>[\\w:]+) # initWithURL:cachePolicy:timeoutInterval:\n \\] # ]\n _\\S+: # _100002060: \n'¶
RE_CATEGORY_CLASS = 'class'¶
RE_CATEGORY_ON_CLASS = 'on_class'¶
RE_CATEGORY_SELECTOR = 'selector'¶
RE_CATEGORY_STATIC_SYMBOL = 'selector_type'¶
RE_CATEGORY_SYMBOL_NON_STATIC = '-'¶
RE_CATEGORY_SYMBOL_STATIC = '+'¶
RE_CLASS_PARENT = '\n Class\\s+ # Class\n (?P<class>\\w+)\\s+ # Object1\n \\(parent\\s+class[:]\\s+ # (parent class: \n (?P<parent>\\w+) # SuperObject)\n \\)\n '¶
RE_CLASS_PARENT_GR_CLASS = 'class'¶
RE_CLASS_PARENT_GR_PARENT = 'parent'¶
RE_C_METHOD = '^\\s+\n _+ # _ \n (?P<c_method_name>\\S+) # CGPointMake_10002c4e0_1\n [:]$'¶
RE_C_METHOD_GR_NAME = 'c_method_name'¶
RE_C_STRING = '\n "(?P<c_string>.*)"\n '¶
RE_C_STRING_GR_NAME = 'c_string'¶
RE_FORMAT_STRING = '\n (?P<objc_string>@?)" # @" or "\n (?P<format_string>\n (?:\n [^%] # match all but %\n | # or\n %%) # %% (escaped %)\n *(?:%.*) # at least one (or more) % followed by alphanumeric or @ is needed \n )\n " # "\n'¶
RE_FORMAT_STRING_GR_OBJC_STRING = 'objc_string'¶
RE_FORMAT_STRING_GR_STRING = 'format_string'¶
RE_HEX_VALUE = '\n \\#? # optional with leading "#" (arm)\n (?P<hex_value>\n 0x[0-9a-zA-Z]+ # 0xFF\n ) \n '¶
RE_HEX_VALUE_GR_HEX_VALUE = 'hex_value'¶
RE_MATCH_ENTRYPOINT = '\\s*EntryPoint:\\s*'¶
RE_METH_IMPL = '\n ^\\s+ # only whitespace at the beginning \n (methImpl|method|meth)[_] # methImpl_ or method_ or meth_\n (?P<static>static)?_? # static_\n (?P<class>([A-Za-z0-9]+[_]*)) # AppDelegate\n [_] # _\n (?P<selector>([A-Za-z0-9]+[_]*)+) # applicationDidFinishLaunching_\n '¶
RE_METH_IMPL_GR_CLASS = 'class'¶
RE_METH_IMPL_GR_SELECTOR = 'selector'¶
RE_METH_IMPL_GR_STATIC = 'static'¶
RE_OWN_C_METHOD_BASE = '\n \\s*\n (?P<name>[^@]*) # match all but @selector(...) - cFunction\n [(] # (\n (?P<args>.*) # int, int, int\n [)] # )\n '¶
RE_OWN_C_METHOD_BASE_GR_ARGS = 'args'¶
RE_OWN_C_METHOD_BASE_GR_NAME = 'name'¶
RE_OWN_C_METHOD_CALLED = '[;]\n \\s*\n (?P<name>[^@]*) # match all but @selector(...) - cFunction\n [(] # (\n (?P<args>.*) # int, int, int\n [)] # )\n '¶
RE_OWN_C_METHOD_DEF = '[/]{2}\n \\s*\n (?P<name>[^@]*) # match all but @selector(...) - cFunction\n [(] # (\n (?P<args>.*) # int, int, int\n [)] # )\n '¶
RE_SELECTOR = '\n @selector\\( # @selector(\n (?P<selector>[\\w:]+) # objectForKey:\n \\) # )\n '¶
RE_SELECTOR_GR_SELECTOR = 'selector'¶
RE_STRING = '\n @" # @"\n (?P<string>.*) # defaults\n " # "\n'¶
RE_STRING_GR_STRING = 'string'¶
RE_SUB = '^\\s+\n (?P<subname>\n sub[_] # sub_\n \\S+) # 1001bc366\n [:]$'¶
RE_SUB_GR_SUBNAME = 'subname'¶
SEARCH_NOP = 'nop'¶
static is_entrypoint(asmline)[source]¶

Check if line is entry point in asm file (See AsmRegEx.RE_MATCH_ENTRYPOINT)

static is_method_implementation(asmline)[source]¶

Indicates if a line is a CategoryClass or method implementation. See AsmRegEx.RE_CATEGORY and AsmRegEx.RE_METH_IMPL.

static method_implementation_is_static(re_meth_impl_gr_static_val)[source]¶

Returns if the method is static

class vizasm.analysis.asm.cpu.AssignmentMatchingSystem.AssignmentMatchingSystem(cpu, parse_util)[source]¶

Bases: object, vizasm.analysis.asm.cpu.Resetable.Resetable

The AssignmentMatchingSystem is the base class for a system that reads a line of assembler code in which an assignment is being made.

The system has to parse the values with the help of the parse_util and wrap them into the appropriate class.

The system also has to recognize stack operations (push and pop).

The left and right object of the assignment can be accessed via lobject and robject but only if an assignment has been made.

If a stack push has been read, the stack can be adjusted with process_stack_push. Reading a stack fetch will store the fetched argument in robject.

If you want to use an estimation for the number of arguments a function takes (not objective-c function) you have to keep track of register and stack usage via reg_usage_since_last_call and `stack_usage_since_last_call.

Parameters:

_cpu: Cpu :

__parse_util: ParseUtil :

the ParseUtil to use for splitting and parsing the line

_lobject: object :

the left value of the assignment matched to a type

_robject: object :

the right value of the assignment matched to a type

_is_stack_fetch: bool (default is False) :

indicates if the assignment is a fetch from the stack e.g. “mov rax, qword [ss:rbp-0x70+arg_8]”

_is_stack_push: bool (default is False) :

indicates if the assignment is a stack push operation. x86_64 example: “mov dword [ss:rsp], 0x7”.

_stack_push_objects: list<object> (default is []) :

the objects being pushed onto the stack

_stack_address: int (default is None) :

the stack address

`: set<Register> :

use to store the registers that have been used to store any value since the last call statement

_stack_usage_since_last_call: set<object> :

use to store the stack arguments that have been used to store any value since the last call statement

c_func_heuristic: bool :

if enabled use heuristic to determine arguments for c function calls

Methods

add_reg_arg_since_last_call(reg, robject) Add a Register to reg_usage_since_last_call if the register is specified as an register holding method arguments.
clear_usage_since_last_call() The Cpu uses this after a new call has been read

read_assignment(asmline) Read an assignment and try to split it.
reset() Use to reset the system after an assignment has been read.

add_reg_arg_since_last_call(reg, robject)[source]¶

Add a Register to reg_usage_since_last_call if the register is specified as an register holding method arguments.

See CallingConventionsInterface.arguments_registers.

Parameters:reg: Register :
c_func_heuristic¶

c_func_heuristic(bool) – if enabled use heuristic to determine arguments for c function calls

clear_usage_since_last_call()[source]¶

The Cpu uses this after a new call has been read to reset the register and stack usage since the last call

Get the registers and stack usage since the last call.

Returns:set<object> :
is_stack_fetch¶

_is_stack_fetch(bool) – indicates if the assignment is a fetch from the stack e.g. “mov rax, qword [ss:rbp-0x70+arg_8]”

is_stack_push¶

_is_stack_push: bool (default is False) – indicates if the assignment is a stack push operation. x86_64 example: “mov dword [ss:rsp], 0x7”.

lobject¶
number_of_arguments_since_last_call()[source]¶

Get the number of arguments that have been seen since the last call. For the arguments going over Register`s only count the ones specified by `CallingConventionsInterface.arguments_registers and only take as much as they are still in the given order. If the Cpu gets its arguments from stack, only take these into account

parse_util¶

__parse_util(ParseUtil) – the ParseUtil to use for splitting and parsing the line

process_stack_push()[source]¶

Push the objects onto the stack

read_assignment(asmline)[source]¶

Read an assignment and try to split it.

Call this first to reset the AssignmentMatchingSystem or do it at your own!

Parameters:

asmline : string

line of assembler
reg_usage_since_last_call¶

reg_usage_since_last_call(set<Register>) – use to store the registers that have been used to store any value since the last call statement

reset()[source]¶

Use to reset the system after an assignment has been read.

robject¶

_robject(object) – the right value of the assignment matched to a type

stack_usage_since_last_call¶

class vizasm.analysis.asm.cpu.CallingConventionsInterface.CallingConventionsInterface[source]¶

Defines the calling conventions of the Cpu

Methods

arguments_registers() List of Register which specifies where the arguments are being stored.
arguments_registers_in_sequence() Return True if the destination_register, selector_register, and the selector_arg_registers are specified one behind the other in arguments_registers.
destination_register() Returns the Register in which the destination for the selector is stored
exclude_argument_regs() Return a list<Register> from which you know,
fetches_all_arguments_from_stack() Return True if all arguments are popped from the stack rather than taking them from registers
floating_arg_registers() The registers which hold the floating-point-numbers
frame_pointer_register() Return the frame pointer register
next_reg_for_spret(register) If an objc_msgSend_stret is detected, the specified Register for the destination and selector do not match anymore due to the fact that the first argument register is needed for the return address of the structure.
next_regs_for_spret(reg_list) Same as next_reg_for_spret, but do it for the whole list of Register
nslog_arg_registers() List of registers which hold the arguments for NSLog
reg_list(regs) Implement this method by calling _reg_list with the register type (reg_typereg_type).
return_reg_is_fst_arg_reg() Check if the return register is also the first argument register
return_register() The register which holds the return value
selector_arg_registers() The registers(list<Register>) where the arguments for the selector are stored.
selector_register() Returns the Register in which the selector is stored
stack_pointer_register() Return the stack pointer as instance of Register.
stret_selector_arg_registers() The registers (list<Register>) where the arguments for the selector are stored.
arguments_registers()[source]¶

List of Register which specifies where the arguments are being stored. If the Cpu fetches its arguments from stack an empty list will be returned.

arguments_registers_in_sequence()[source]¶

Return True if the destination_register, selector_register, and the selector_arg_registers are specified one behind the other in arguments_registers.

destination_register()[source]¶

Returns the Register in which the destination for the selector is stored

exclude_argument_regs()[source]¶

Return a list<Register> from which you know, that they will not be used to hold arguments for a function call

fetches_all_arguments_from_stack()[source]¶

Return True if all arguments are popped from the stack rather than taking them from registers

floating_arg_registers()[source]¶

The registers which hold the floating-point-numbers

frame_pointer_register()[source]¶

Return the frame pointer register

next_reg_for_spret(register)[source]¶

If an objc_msgSend_stret is detected, the specified Register for the destination and selector do not match anymore due to the fact that the first argument register is needed for the return address of the structure. This means that all Register get shifted right. At least if arguments_registers_in_sequence. Otherwise you have to implement this yourself!

Parameters:register: Register :
next_regs_for_spret(reg_list)[source]¶

Same as next_reg_for_spret, but do it for the whole list of Register

nslog_arg_registers()[source]¶

List of registers which hold the arguments for NSLog

reg_list(regs)[source]¶

Implement this method by calling _reg_list with the register type (reg_typereg_type).

Parameters:regs: list<string> :
Returns:list<reg_type> :
return_reg_is_fst_arg_reg()[source]¶

Check if the return register is also the first argument register

return_register()[source]¶

The register which holds the return value

selector_arg_registers()[source]¶

The registers(list<Register>) where the arguments for the selector are stored. If the selector needs more arguments, the remaining ones are taken from the stack

selector_register()[source]¶

Returns the Register in which the selector is stored

stack_pointer_register()[source]¶

Return the stack pointer as instance of Register. E.g. “rsp” on x86_64.

stret_selector_arg_registers()[source]¶

The registers (list<Register>) where the arguments for the selector are stored. They are only used for a objc_msgSend_stret(). A message with a structure as return value. The first parameters will be used as an address where the structure is returned. So the first Register of selector_arg_registers will be cut off.

class vizasm.analysis.asm.cpu.Cpu.Cpu(assignment_matching_system, parse_util, _register_class, superclass_dict=None, objc_runtime=None)[source]¶

Bases: object, vizasm.analysis.asm.cpu.CRuntime.CRuntime, vizasm.analysis.asm.cpu.CallingConventionsInterface.CallingConventionsInterface, vizasm.analysis.asm.cpu.Resetable.Resetable

The Cpu is the heart of VizAsm.

It reads and interprets the asm file (use read_line). and keeps track of the StackFrame and the `Register`s.

It stores the method calls that have been made in the MethodCall (stores the calls for a single method implementation).

Every time you read a new method implementation, you should reset the Cpu.

Parameters:

_memory: Memory :

the memory of the cpu

_objc_runtime: ObjectiveCRuntime, optional (default is ObjectiveCRuntime) :

the objective-c runtime

__assignment_matching_system: AssignmentMatchingSystem :

the system to read assignments

_parse_util: ParseUtil :

utility for parsing the asm file

_register_class: classobj :

subclass of Register (only the reference!). this class reference is used to create the correct register subclass depending on the cpu architecture.

_linenumber: int :

the current line number in the asm file. Given as parameter in read_line.

__address: int :

the address of the current asm line

_method: FunctionInterface :

the method which is currently being analyzed

__method_call: MethodCall :

This is the actual output of the Cpu. It stores the messages that have been read.

c_func_heuristic: bool :

if enabled use heuristic to determine arguments for c function calls

Notes

Subclasses need to implement CallingConventionsInterface as well as:
create_and_store_method_selector_arguments ignore_hex_addr_call

Methods

arguments_registers() List of Register which specifies where the arguments are being stored.
arguments_registers_in_sequence() Return True if the destination_register, selector_register, and the selector_arg_registers are specified one behind the other in arguments_registers.
create_and_store_c_func_arguments(method) Create and store the arguments for the function.
destination_register() Returns the Register in which the destination for the selector is stored
exclude_argument_regs() Return a list<Register> from which you know,
fetches_all_arguments_from_stack() Return True if all arguments are popped from the stack rather than taking them from registers

next_reg_for_spret(register) If an objc_msgSend_stret is detected, the specified Register for the destination and selector do not match anymore due to the fact that the first argument register is needed for the return address of the structure.
next_regs_for_spret(reg_list) Same as next_reg_for_spret, but do it for the whole list of Register

return_reg_is_fst_arg_reg() Check if the return register is also the first argument register
return_register() The register which holds the return value
selector_arg_registers() The registers(list<Register>) where the arguments for the selector are stored.

read_line(asmline, linenr=None)[source]¶

Read a line of the asm file and process the information to keep track of the registers and stack.

Parameters:

asmline: string :

a line of assembler

linenr: int, optional :

the current line number in the file. If not given, it will not be used in the output.
Raises:

CpuException :

if any underlying exception has been raised
register_class¶

_register_clas(classobj) – subclass of Register (only the reference!). This class reference is used to create the correct register subclass depending on the cpu architecture

cpu¶
static get_address_from_asmline(asmline)[source]¶

Get the hex address of the current line. This is the first number of the line. Return it as int or None if not available.

static get_fst_match(asmline, functionlist)[source]¶

Get the first function (lazy) that matches on the given input argument.

Parameters:

asmline: string :

the argument to apply on the functions

functionlist: list<functionrefs> :

the functions on which to apply the input argument
static get_fst_match_bool_list(asmline, functionlist)[source]¶

Get the first function (lazy) that matches on the given input argument.

Parameters:

asmline: string :

the argument to apply on the functions

functionlist: list<functionrefs> :

the functions on which to apply the input argument
Returns:

tuple<list<bool>, object> :

Return a list where the function that matched has a True entry and the rest False. The second argument of the tuple is the return value of the function that matched.

register: `register_type` :

None :

parse_selector(asmline)[source]¶

If annotated by Hopper, the Selector will be created from this. Otherwise implement this method yourself!

parse_stack_access(asmline)[source]¶

Parse a stack access like e.g. “[sp, #0x8]” or “[r7, #0x8]” or “[sp] (arm). The latter should lead to an address of 0x0.

Returns:

tuple<string, string> :

Return the stack pointer name as well as the stack address as hex string.
parse_stackvar(asmline)[source]¶
parse_string(asmline)[source]¶

Parse a string and return the appropriate string class.

Returns:

FormatString, NSString or string :

None :

if nothing matches
parse_var_assignment(asmline)[source]¶

Wrapper for parse_var_assignment_with_ivar_ref_from_asmline. Ignores nop operations e.g. “nop dword [ds:rax+0x0]”

Create a VarAssignment from a line of assembler (like e.g. “[ds:rax+rcx]”, x86_64 example

If the asmline has the form of “[ds:rdx+rsi], rax” the ivar_ref will be resolved. But the part after the comma can be left out.

Based on this method (more general parse_var_assignment_with_ivar_ref_from_asmline), the Cpu keeps an instance variable cache. See IVarRefLookup.

Parameters:

asmline: string :
Returns:

VarAssignment :

the VarAssignment with ivar_ref set (if possible)

None :

if no VarAssignment
Raises:

VarAssignmentResolveSelfrefRegisterException :

if the value cannot be resolved

VarAssignmentResolveIvarRegisterException :

if the value cannot be resolved

VarAssignmentIvarRegisterWrongTypeException :

if the type of the ivar_reg is not IVar
parse_var_assignment_with_ivar_ref_from_asmline(asmline)[source]¶

Create a VarAssignment from a line of assembler (like e.g. “[ds:rax+rcx]”, x86_64 example)

If the asmline has the form of “[ds:rdx+rsi], rax” the ivar_ref will be resolved. But the part after the comma can be left out.

Based on this method the Cpu keeps an instance variable cache. See IVarRefLookup.

Parameters:

asmline: string :
Returns:

VarAssignment :

the VarAssignment with ivar_ref set (if possible)

None :
Raises:

VarAssignmentResolveSelfrefRegisterException :

if the value cannot be resolved

VarAssignmentResolveIvarRegisterException :

if the value cannot be resolved

VarAssignmentIvarRegisterWrongTypeException :

if the type of the ivar_reg is not IVar
parse_var_assignment_without_ivar_ref_from_asmline(asmline)[source]¶

Create a VarAssignment from asmline like e.g. “[ds:rax+rcx] (x86_64 example) “

Parameters:

asmline: String :
Returns:

VarAssignment :

the VarAssignment without ivar_ref set (None if no VarAssignment)
Raises:

VarAssignmentResolveSelfrefRegisterException :

if the value cannot be resolved

VarAssignmentResolveIvarRegisterException :

if the value cannot be resolved and resolve_ivar_value is true

VarAssignmentIvarRegisterWrongTypeException :

if the type of the ivar_reg is not IVar and `resolve_ivar_value is true
